prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal (1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup No.1 for 3mm line survey toward NGC 7469. LSB: 85.45 - 89.25 GHz USB: 97.65 - 101.45 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In this setup, we will use four basebands, each consists of one spectral window of 1.875 GHz width. Frequency ranges of 85.45 - 89.25 GHz (LSB) and 97.65 - 101.45 GHz (USB) will be covered in this setup. The channels will be smoothed to a requested velocity resolution of 30 km/s, considering the large velocity width (FWZI ~ 500 km/s, FWHM ~ 250 km/s; Fig.2b of SJ) of molecular line emissions in the nuclear region of NGC 7469.
Note that we need all of the observed data, even if no line is detected (non-detection is also meaningful), since this is a "line survey" program. Hence, please do not cut off any of the achieved data.

We request the same angular resolution to our Band 7 data of HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), CS(7-6), and CO(3-2) line emissions, successfully obtained in Cycle 1 with ALMA, in order to take line ratios and/or to conduct non-LTE radiative transfer calculations with the same resolution data. Therefore, the requested angular resolution is 0".5, which corresponds to ~ 165 pc at the distance of NGC 7469 (D = 70.1 Mpc).
The largest angular scale is ~ 5-6", which is the diameter of the starburst ring of NGC 7469 (Fig.2a of SJ). This can be entirely covered with the maximum recoverable scale achievable in this observation.

We request the sensitivity of 0.35 mJy in 0".5 beam, at the velocity resolution of 30 km/s, for all Science Goals, since this is a line survey project. The requested velocity resolution is high enough to resolve the wide line width of molecular emission lines in the nucleus of NGC 7469 (FWHM ~ 250 km/s, FWZI ~ 500 km/s; Fig.2b of SJ). Moreover, we can discuss molecular gas kinematics using bright lines such as CO(1-0) and HCN(1-0) with this velocity resolution.
In this setup, SiO, C2H, and CS, will be observed, for example. We start our sensitivity estimation from the HCN(4-3) peak flux density, 22 mJy (our Cycle 1 result; Fig.2b of SJ), since the angular resolution for this HCN(4-3) observation is the same as the one we here request. Then, assuming an averaged value of HCN(1-0)/HCN(4-3) flux ratio of ~ 0.2 (Fig.2c of SJ), the expected peak flux density of HCN(1-0) emission is ~ 4.4 mJy per 0".5 beam. Note that we put this flux density into the "Field Setup" panel of all Science Goals for convenience, but it does not have a strong meaning since this program is a unbiased line survey observation and thus we do not aim at detecting a specific emission line.
Next, we assume NGC 7469 has similar line ratios to those of the circumnuclear disk (CND) in NGC 1097, obtained in our Cycle 0 program (Martin et al. 2015, A&A, 573, 116). Note that we here estimate line fluxes of the CND of NGC 7469 as a representative region. To estimate the flux density of the CND, we should avoid applying line ratios obtained with single dish telescopes, since single dish observations usually mix emission from AGN and that from a surrounding star forming region.
As a result, we estimate the peak flux densities of, e.g., SiO(2-1) and HNCO(4-3). With the requested sensitivity of 0.35 mJy, we will detect HCN(1-0) at ~ 13 sigma significance. As for faint lines, we will degrade the velocity resolution from 30 km/s to ~ 100 km/s. Note that the FWHM and FWZI of molecular emission lines at nucleus of NGC 7469 are quite wide, namely, ~ 250 km/s and ~ 500 km/s, respectively (Fig.2b of SJ). This degraded velocity resolution is of course insufficient to discuss molecular gas kinematics, but it is still sufficient just to "detect" emission lines. With this treatment, we will detect peak flux density of faint lines comparable to SiO(2-1) and HNCO(4-3) at, a few sigma and ~ 5 sigma significance, respectively. This means we can expect higher significance detection in integrated intensity maps.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal (2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup No.1 for 3mm line survey toward NGC 7469. LSB: 89.25 - 93.00 GHz USB: 102.17 - 105.05 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:

Frequency ranges of 89.25 - 93.00 GHz (LSB) and 102.17 - 105.05 GHz (USB) will be covered in this setup. With this treatment, we will detect peak flux density of faint lines comparable to SiO(2-1) and HNCO(4-3) at, a few sigma and ~ 5 sigma significance, respectively. This means we can expect higher significance detection in integrated intensity maps.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal (4)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup No.3 for 3mm line survey toward NGC 7469. LSB: 96.80 - 100.60 GHz USB: 108.95 - 112.70 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In this setup, we will use four basebands, each consists of one spectral window of 1.875 GHz width. Frequency ranges of 96.80 - 100.60 GHz (LSB) and 108.95 - 112.70 GHz (USB) will be covered in this setup. The channels will be smoothed to a requested velocity resolution of 30 km/s, considering the large velocity width (FWZI ~ 500 km/s, FWHM ~ 250 km/s; Fig.2b of SJ) of molecular line emissions in the nuclear region of NGC 7469.
Note that we need all of the observed data, even if no line is detected (non-detection is also meaningful), since this is a "line survey" program. Hence, please do not cut off any of the achieved data.

We request the same angular resolution to our Band 7 data of HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), CS(7-6), and CO(3-2) line emissions, successfully obtained in Cycle 1 with ALMA, in order to take line ratios and/or to conduct non-LTE radiative transfer calculations with the same resolution data. Moreover, we can discuss molecular gas kinematics using bright lines such as CO(1-0) and HCN(1-0) with this velocity resolution.
In this setup, HNCO, 13CO, and CH3CN, will be observed, for example. We start our sensitivity estimation from the HCN(4-3) peak flux density, 22 mJy (our Cycle 1 result; Fig.2b of SJ), since the angular resolution for this HCN(4-3) observation is the same as the one we here request. As for faint lines, we will degrade the velocity resolution from 30 km/s to ~ 100 km/s. This degraded velocity resolution is of course insufficient to discuss molecular gas kinematics, but it is still sufficient just to "detect" emission lines. With this treatment, we will detect peak flux density of faint lines comparable to SiO(2-1) and HNCO(4-3) at, a few sigma and ~ 5 sigma significance, respectively. This means we can expect higher significance detection in integrated intensity maps.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal (5)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup No.3 for 3mm line survey toward NGC 7469. LSB: 112.65 - 116.40 GHz USB: not assigned

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In this setup, we will use four basebands, each consists of one spectral window of 1.875 GHz width. Frequency range of 112.65 - 116.40 GHz (LSB) will be covered in this setup. We do not need the data of USB in this time. The channels will be smoothed to a requested velocity resolution of 30 km/s, considering the large velocity width (FWZI ~ 500 km/s, FWHM ~ 250 km/s; Fig.2b of SJ) of molecular line emissions in the nuclear region of NGC 7469.
Note that we need all of the observed data, even if no line is detected (non-detection is also meaningful), since this is a "line survey" program. Hence, please do not cut off any of the achieved data.

We request the same angular resolution to our Band 7 data of HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), CS(7-6), and CO(3-2) line emissions, successfully obtained in Cycle 1 with ALMA, in order to take line ratios and/or to conduct non-LTE radiative transfer calculations with the same resolution data. Therefore, the requested angular resolution is 0".5, which corresponds to ~ 165 pc at the distance of NGC 7469 (D = 70.1 Mpc).
The largest angular scale is ~ 5-6", which is the diameter of the starburst ring of NGC 7469 (Fig.2a of SJ). This can be entirely covered with the maximum recoverable scale achievable in this observation.

We request the sensitivity of 0.35 mJy in 0".5 beam, at the velocity resolution of 30 km/s, for all Science Goals, since this is a line survey project. The requested velocity resolution is high enough to resolve the wide line width of molecular emission lines in the nucleus of NGC 7469 (FWHM ~ 250 km/s, FWZI ~ 500 km/s; Fig.2b of SJ). Moreover, we can discuss molecular gas kinematics using bright lines such as CO(1-0) and HCN(1-0) with this velocity resolution.
In this setup, 12CN and 12CO, will be observed, for example. We start our sensitivity estimation from the HCN(4-3) peak flux density, 22 mJy (our Cycle 1 result; Fig.2b of SJ), since the angular resolution for this HCN(4-3) observation is the same as the one we here request. Then, assuming an averaged value of HCN(1-0)/HCN(4-3) flux ratio of ~ 0.2 (Fig.2c of SJ), the expected peak flux density of HCN(1-0) emission is ~ 4.4 mJy per 0".5 beam. As a result, we estimate the peak flux densities of, e.g., SiO(2-1) and HNCO(4-3). With the requested sensitivity of 0.35 mJy, we will detect HCN(1-0) at ~ 13 sigma significance. As for faint lines, we will degrade the velocity resolution from 30 km/s to ~ 100 km/s. Note that the FWHM and FWZI of molecular emission lines at nucleus of NGC 7469 are quite wide, namely, ~ 250 km/s and ~ 500 km/s, respectively (Fig.2b of SJ). This degraded velocity resolution is of course insufficient to discuss molecular gas kinematics, but it is still sufficient just to "detect" emission lines. With this treatment, we will detect peak flux density of faint lines comparable to SiO(2-1) and HNCO(4-3) at, a few sigma and ~ 5 sigma significance, respectively. This means we can expect higher significance detection in integrated intensity maps.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to conduct a line survey toward the central kpc region of the nearby type-1 Seyfert galaxy NGC 7469, at 3 mm bands (86-116 GHz). Thanks to the high resolution achievable with ALMA, we can separate the circumnucear disk and the starburst ring with a radius of 1".5, which is essential to make a clean spectral template of both AGN and starburst.
By combining our Band 7 data of HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), CS(7-6), and CO(3-2), we will conduct non-LTE line modeling to estimate abundance variation of these molecules at the nuclear region. For other molecules detected at Band 3, we assume their excitation temperature and the LTE condition to estimate their abundances.
Although many topics can be studied in this work, We will investigate abudance variation of (1) HCN and HCO+ over the nuclear region, (2) molecules sensitive to UV radiation field, and (3) dust-related molecules such as CH3OH, CH3CN.
All observed properties will be extensively compared with chemical models and other results of line surveys toward nearby galaxies, to further understand the effect of AGN on the surrounding material.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: T. Izumi et al. 2012.1.00165.S, "The Quest for a robust AGN diagnostic in the (sub-)millimeter domain" (Cycle 1) T. Izumi et al. 2013.1.00218.S, "Spatially resolved 3 mm imaging line survey toward NGC 7469" (Cycle 2)
